diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain. It commonly presents with pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, leukopenia, and arthritis which may manifest as synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can cause pleural effusion and pericardial effusion, and synovitis is one of the hallmark symptoms. Leukopenia is less common but can occur, particularly in patients with Felty's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can also cause systemic symptoms, including joint inflammation (synovitis), pleural effusion, and in severe cases, leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It is associated with other systemic symptoms, including pleural effusion. Follicular hyperkeratosis could be related to the skin manifestations of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder displaying features of three other connective tissue diseases—systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis, and scleroderma—and sometimes rheumatoid arthritis. Symptoms can include pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, leukopenia, and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause pleural and pericardial effusions secondary to lymphatic obstruction or infiltration. Leukopenia can occur due to bone marrow involvement. Although less common, lymphoma can also present with other symptoms such as follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In skin, it can cause lesions that may mimic follicular hyperkeratosis. It can also cause pleural effusion, though that's less common.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus infection and acquired immune deficiency syndrome can present with a wide array of symptoms, including leukopenia due to the immunocompromising nature of the disease. Follicular hyperkeratosis, synovitis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can also be features in various stages of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A severe infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs but can affect other parts of the body. It can cause pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and in severe cases, leukopenia. Synovitis can be a manifestation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes a hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can feature pericardial effusion and synovitis, alongside other systemic symptoms. Follicular hyperkeratosis can be part of the skin symptoms.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C Related Nephritis
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
HIV/AIDS with related opportunistic infections or Kaposi sarcoma
Tick-borne Diseases (e.g., Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjogren's Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., ANCA-associated, Central Nervous System Vasculitis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, bacterial, viral, or fungal infections)
Schizophrenia (or other primary psychotic disorders, for psychosis symptom)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Dysmenorrhea
diagnoses.description: Painful menstruation that usually begins at ovulation and ends with menstruation. It's not associated with any specific pelvic disorder.

diagnoses.name: Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)
diagnoses.description: A group of changes that happen before a woman's monthly period, including psychological symptoms such as irritability, and physical symptoms like bloating and headache.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalance
diagnoses.description: Dysfunction in hormone levels that can lead to a variety of symptoms including irregular menstruation, mood swings, and unusual body reactions like angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) such as changes in vision, sensory disturbances, and sometimes speech problems, which can precede the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A variety of disorders characterized by excessive fear and anxiety that can manifest physically as angioedema or seizures, and psychologically as irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes severe swelling, particularly of the face and airways, and abdominal cramping.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus grows outside your uterus, causing pain, sometimes severe, especially during menstruation.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Exposure
diagnoses.description: Exposure to toxic substances can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms such as seizures and sensory disturbances (dysosmia), as well as hormonal imbalances affecting menstruation.

diagnoses: Oral Cancer (related to leukoplakia and poor healing)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by recurrent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors (compulsions).

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation, including arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels or dysfunction of the von Willebrand factor, which can lead to symptoms like dysmenorrhea due to heavy menstrual bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges, which can lead to symptoms such as dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where antibodies attack the person's own red blood cells, leading to increased production of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer formed by malignant plasma cells. Characterized by an overproduction of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue that normally lines the uterus grows outside the uterus, leading to symptoms such as dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disease
diagnoses.description: Disorders in which part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, sometimes characterized by an increase in certain types of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry, and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it. It can present with obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM syndromes
diagnoses.description: Group of rare disorders characterized by an abnormal increase in the levels of immunoglobulin M (IgM) due to a defect in the class switch recombination process.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Nutritional Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin C Deficiency leading to Scurvy)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: A persistent infection or inflammation of the middle ear, commonly associated with fluid buildup. May correlate with difficulty focusing vision if it affects the Eustachian tube or inner ear structures.

diagnoses.name: Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E Syndrome (Job's Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A rare immunodeficiency disorder characterized by high levels of serum immunoglobulin E (IgE). Patients may experience recurrent infections, including otitis media, and could potentially exhibit features related to anxiety or physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A common immunodeficiency that can lead to increased infections such as otitis media. Individuals may develop compensatory mechanisms, including increased levels of other immunoglobulins. Anxiety and sensitivity could be secondary to chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that involves low levels of most or all of the immunoglobulin classes. This can lead to frequent infections such as otitis media. Some patients might experience increased certain immunoglobulin classes in an attempt to compensate. Chronic disease can lead to anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth but can also cause chronic ear infections (otitis media) due to decreased mucosal secretions. Systemic effects might include a broad spectrum of immunoglobulin abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can influence immunoglobulin levels and lead to various physical sensitivities, including altered visual acuity. Anxiety is a common symptom of thyroid dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Although not directly associated with increased immunoglobulins or otitis media, fibromyalgia can cause significant physical sensitivities and anxiety. Vision difficulties can also occur but are more typically related to the fibro fog phenomenon.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause optic neuritis, leading to vision difficulties. Anxiety and physical sensitivities are common among MS patients. Immune dysregulation may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the nervous system and skin, causing a wide range of symptoms such as anxiety and physical sensitivities. Lupus can lead to increased levels of certain immunoglobulins and recurrent otitis media due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions like anxiety disorder can manifest with various physical symptoms, including heightened physical sensitivities. Though less directly related to immunoglobulin levels or otitis media, the impact of chronic anxiety on the immune system shouldn't be underestimated.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse health effect arising from a specific immune response that occurs reproducibly on exposure to a given food.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A serious, life-threatening allergic reaction that can affect several areas of the body simultaneously.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting the intestine (bowel) which is characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both).

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Esophagitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic inflammatory condition of the esophagus that involves eosinophils, a type of white blood cell.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: Term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition in which hives occur without a known cause, often accompanied by angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic Infections
diagnoses.description: Infections caused by parasites, which can affect the gastrointestinal tract and cause symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Lactose Intolerance
diagnoses.description: The inability to fully digest lactose, the sugar in milk, which can lead to diarrhea, gas, and bloating after dairy consumption.

diagnoses: Common cold or upper respiratory infection
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Migraine without aura (considering headache as a primary symptom)
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe head pain, nausea, weakness, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke can cause sudden numbness, weakness (especially on one side of the body), and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: MS can lead to numbness, weakness, and sometimes nausea as part of its symptom complex.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: Damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves) can cause numbness, weakness, and occasionally nausea.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.details: Lack of vitamin B12 can lead to numbness, weakness, fatigue, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A brain tumor can cause nausea, numbness, and weakness depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: This rare disorder causes your body's immune system to attack your nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and might cause nausea.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: A complication of diabetes that affects nerves, leading to numbness, weakness, and possibly nausea.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: Underactive thyroid can lead to a variety of symptoms including weakness, numbness, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.details: Severe dehydration can produce nausea, muscle weakness, and numbness in extreme cases.

diagnoses: Psoriatic Arthritis (less common for discoid rash)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, hepatitis, Epstein-Barr virus)
Sjögren's Syndrome with neurological and renal involvement
Drug Reactions (Drug-induced lupus, other drug-related syndromes)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, skin, and blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause pleural effusions and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect various organs, causing granulomas. It can lead to lung involvement, skin lesions, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, potentially causing pleural effusion, anemia, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels, which can affect multiple organs and systems.

diagnoses.name: Infections (e.g., Tuberculosis)
diagnoses.description: Certain infections can cause pleural effusions, anemia, and systemic symptoms like fevers and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus can cause a wide range of symptoms including anemia, and indirectly lead to pleural effusions and panniculitis.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis
diagnoses.description: A specific type of vasculitis that can cause kidney problems (proteinuria), lung issues, and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that results from the abnormal premature destruction of red blood cells. Can cause kidney failure and lead to proteinuria and anemia.
